subject: Are you looking for a new way to deal with pain, anxiety, depression, or difficult interactions with others?
author: kmeason
content:
The UNC Foundations of Mindfulness: Introduction to Mindfulness Based Stress & Pain Management (MSPM) with Kessonga Giscombe

Sponsored by the UNC Program on Integrative Medicine  

Are you looking for a new way to deal with pain, anxiety, depression, or difficult interactions with others
Do you want to learn to slow down and enjoy your life more
The UNC Foundations of Mindfulness: Introduction to Mindfulness Based Stress & Pain Management (MSPM) with Kessonga Giscombe offers training in meditation and mind-body awareness that will teach you how to slow down, set priorities and stay calm, focused and relaxed in the midst of a busy life.  These practices will enhance your body's natural adaptive healing ability and will cultivate the mind's clarity and insight.


This program follows Jon Kabat-Zinn's model and is offered by the Program on Integrative Medicine at UNC (Department of Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation).

Class Dates: Wednesday, May 16 through July 11, 2018, from 6-8:30pm (no class on July 4!)

Location: UNC School of Social Work,  Tate-Turner-Kuralt Building, Room 500, 27599, 325 Pittsboro St #3550, Chapel Hill, NC 27516  Free parking available, if needed.

To Register, please click here! 

About the Instructor, Kessonga Giscombe

Kessonga is a Licensed Acupuncturist, Certified Holistic Health Counselor, and Mindfulness Meditation Instructor. He holds a Bachelor's Degree in Biology and a Master's of Science degree in Acupuncture from The New York College of Health Professions.  He specializes in Japanese Meridian Therapy as well as Traditional Chinese Acupuncture.      

Questions? Please class 919-966-8586

For more information, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfulness@med.unc.edu 

Please visit our website  for additional course information and like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: DDD-Announcement regarding Dwayne Pinkney, Chief Financial Officer and Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations
author: jlkelly
content:
To:                   Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

From:               Jonathan Pruitt, Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations

Date:                May 4, 2018

Subject:            Announcement regarding Dwayne Pinkney, Chief Financial Officer and Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations

 

I am writing to let you know that Dwayne Pinkney has decided to conclude his service as Chief Financial Officer and Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations to accept a new opportunity at Virginia Tech as Senior Vice President for Operations and Administration starting Aug. 1.  Dwayne’s last day at Carolina will be July 31.  

Dwayne’s support as strategic adviser and principal deputy in Finance and Operations has been critical during recent F&O leadership transitions. Additionally, his oversight of the University’s financial, budget, and accounting operations and his leadership for the division’s shared administrative and business services functions has been essential to maintaining our service levels to campus while improving our processes.

During the past 14 years of Dwayne’s progression through the university ranks, he has been and continues to be a steadfast and respected leader. I have personally known Dwayne for most of those 14 years and believe that his integrity and commitment to this university has been an inspiration for many of us. 

Dwayne’s Carolina roots run deep. He earned his Ph.D. in political science here, and he and his wife have two sons who are students in UNC System schools. Dwayne was promoted to his current position in December 2016 after serving as vice provost for finance and academic planning since 2010 and secretary of the university since 2014. Previously, he served as the assistant vice chancellor for finance and administration and special assistant to the Chancellor for state and local relations. Prior to joining UNC-Chapel Hill in 2004, Pinkney was an associate vice president for finance for the UNC System and spent six years as a fiscal analyst with the North Carolina General Assembly.

During his time as CFO and Senior Associate Vice Chancellor, he was instrumental in establishing a framework for consolidated administrative and business service functions for F&O. He has partnered with the provost’s office and university leaders to improve the University’s process for resource management, planning and allocation – our new budget model – which is central to The Blueprint for Next.  From his earliest days with the University, Dwayne has been a leader in efforts to improve University operations.  In 2007, he led the University’s participation in the President’s Advisory Commission on Efficiency and Effectiveness (PACE), serving as the primary liaison between the University and UNC General Administration.  Throughout his tenure as Vice Provost for Finance and Academic Planning, he led the University’s tuition and fee planning process, resulting in increased tuition receipts for the professional schools.  Dwayne also supported the planning of off-the-model tuition programs for schools seeking to start new programs without appropriations from the legislature.

We will continue to provide you with updates related to this transition. Please join me in thanking Dwayne for his many years of leadership and dedication to Carolina. We wish him the very best.

Note: This memo is also being sent to University Business Managers.
comments: Please send Monday, May 7 prior to Noon if possible.

subject: Healthy volunteers needed!
author: grewen
content:
Healthy volunteers needed!

The UNC-Chapel Hill School of Medicine is seeking healthy volunteers for a research study monitoring changes in brain functioning through five study visits over an 8 month time period.

You may be eligible for this study if:
• You are between the ages of 12 and 17
• You have no acute or chronic illnesses
• You are able to come to UNC for regular study visits

Study visits will include questions about mental and physical health, tests of memory and attention, MRI, EEG and a blood draw. Compensation for completing all study evaluations is $1290.

In order to find out whether you are eligible,
visit http://www.med.unc.edu/psych/cecmh/oasis/research
and click on “Join our Research Registry”
or call (877) PRIME-19 or (877) 774-6319

People under the age of 18 will need permission from a parent
or guardian prior to completing the questionnaire.

Reach out to

PRIME (Prevention through Risk Identification Management & Education)

 

 

This project is funded by the National Institute of Mental Health
University of North Carolina
Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Human Subjects
The BioMedical IRB
IRB #14-2055

Approved 6-11-2015

subject: Winners Selected for UNC Creativity Hubs Inaugural Awards
author: briordan
content:
Date:  May 4, 2018
To:      Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs
From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research
Re:      Winners Selected for UNC Creativity Hubs Inaugural Awards

Dear Colleagues,

I am pleased to announce that winning teams have been selected for the inaugural UNC Creativity Hubs award. The winning research teams are pursuing solutions to two of the world’s most pressing issues: the obesity epidemic and the global clean water shortage.

The Creativity Hubs initiative was developed to support the Carolina Blueprint for Next strategic framework, and is a platform on which research teams are assembled from diverse disciplines to tackle major societal challenges.

Leveraging the strengths of Carolina’s schools of medical and health sciences, its affiliated research centers and institutes, and its prowess in big data management, the Heterogeneity in Obesity Creativity Hub, led by Penny Gordon-Larsen, professor of nutrition in the UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health,  will take a novel approach to assess the underlying causes of obesity, tapping information that has not been traditionally studied to unlock new, targeted ways to treat the disease.

By developing an automated tool to rapidly analyze and integrate large data sets, the team will seek answers to why individuals with the same diet experience weight gain and loss differently. Their research is expected to lead to more personalized treatments that take into account the wide range of factors — from diet, to social influences, to genetics — that contribute to weight gain and loss. 

Addressing a need that affects over 1.8 billion people worldwide, the Sustainable Access to Clean Water Creativity Hub, led by Theo Dingemans, professor of applied physical science in the College of Arts and Sciences, will pursue development of an innovative, affordable membrane-based water purification solution that can safely remove a broad range of water contaminants.

The project team is comprised of polymer chemists, computational modelers, and engineers from the College of Arts & Sciences’ Applied Physical Sciences and Mathematics departments and the Gillings School of Global Public Health. Building on existing graphene and graphene oxide membrane technologies that have shown promise as water purifiers, the team will seek to develop new filters that make water purification more energy-efficient and to lay a foundation for large-scale, affordable membrane production.

The Creativity Hubs initiative was developed by the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research to foster fluid, cross-disciplinary research, to establish campus networks that nurture research innovation and risk-taking, and to promote a pervasive culture that drives discovery and curiosity. The inaugural winners of the Creativity Hubs awards were selected from proposals involving 194 UNC researchers from 35 departments in 10 schools and the College of Arts & Sciences. Each team will receive up to $250,000 toward the development of their proposals. Progress will be assessed after one year and the teams could be eligible for up to an additional $250,000 in funding.

For more information on the UNC Creativity Hubs initiative and the winning teams, please visit: research.unc.edu/creativity-hubs.

subject: UNC Collective Investment Trust
author: kirkkm
content:
The University of North Carolina System is committed to periodically reviewing its retirement programs to make sure they continue to help you meet your retirement and financial goals. Among the things considered are the range of investment options available through the plans, investment option performance and value, and the resources available to help you manage your account. 

As a result of a recent review, the UNC System has decided to make the following changes to the investment lineup for both the UNC Optional Retirement Plan (ORP) and the UNC System 457(b) Plan effective May 7, 2018. 

Please note these changes will not apply to the UNC System 403(b) Plan due to current federal regulations; however, the UNC System Office is contacting the Internal Revenue Service to determine if the new investment funds can be made available in the UNC System 403(b) Plan at a later date.

The purpose of this email is to inform you of these changes and how you may be affected. You do not need to take any action.

WHAT’S CHANGING

The UNC System will replace the 12 Vanguard Target Retirement Funds currently offered in the ORP and UNC System 457(b) Plan with Vanguard Target Retirement Trusts.

The Vanguard Target Retirement Funds currently offered in the plans are mutual funds. The new Vanguard Target Retirement Trusts are commingled trusts. Trusts operate like mutual funds but are available only to institutional investors, including you as a participant in the ORP and/or UNC System 457(b) Plan.

Funds and trusts often invest in the same underlying securities and have the same objectives. Because trusts are only offered to institutions that have more money to invest, they can achieve greater efficiency and charge lower expense ratios than mutual funds. This reduces the overall cost for you to invest in them. (See the chart below for the expense ratios of the current and new investment options.)

The new Vanguard Target Retirement Trusts will be available to all ORP and UNC System 457(b) Plan participants beginning May 7, 2018. For more information about the new trusts, click here or visit the Vanguard Target Retirement Trust website at https://retirementplans.vanguard.com/ekit/pmed/trf/index.html?&opw&UNC&.

Please note that since the Vanguard Target Retirement Trusts are only available to institutional investors, you will not be able to monitor their investment returns through a service such as Morningstar. You will need to visit your investment carrier’s website for the latest information. You may also visit the Vanguard Target Retirement Trust website and select How to Choose One. Here you will find links to the Target Retirement Trust fact sheets. The fact sheets contain the latest investment information and are updated at the end of each month.

If you are currently investing in one of the Vanguard Target Retirement Funds, the chart below shows how the current investment options will map to the new investment options.



Expense ratio information as of March 27, 2018.

What You Need to Do
You do not need to do anything. When the market closes on May 7, 2018, all existing balances in the Vanguard Target Retirement Funds will be automatically transferred to the Vanguard Retirement Trusts as indicated in the chart above. In addition, any future contributions will be invested in the new investment trust as shown above, unless you contact TIAA or Fidelity to change your contributions.

You will receive a confirmation statement from your retirement carrier. Changes to your account(s) will also be noted online and on your next statement.

If you do not want your existing balances and future contributions to transfer as shown above, you must contact your investment carrier directly before 4:00 p.m. ET on May 4, 2018, and request a change.

Questions?
If you would like more information about the new investment options, or to review existing investment options in your plan, please contact your carrier directly.

Don’t forget, you can change your current contribution allocation and current balance asset allocation at any time by contacting TIAA or Fidelity directly.

TIAA
By phone: 800-842-2252, Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. and Saturday, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., Eastern Time
Online: tiaa.org/unc
Fidelity
By phone: 800-343-0860, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Eastern Time
Online: http://www.netbenefits.com/unc 

You can also contact your campus HR/benefits representative.

subject: Night sweats? Feeling down?
author: anitaa
content:
Help us learn about how hormones improve mood by joining our research study.

You may be eligible if:

You are a woman age 44-55;
Your periods are irregular;
You’ve had a period in the last year.
 If you’re feeling down, sad, or annoyed, you may qualify for our study.  Our study involves taking estrogen for 3 weeks, having 2 brain scans at UNC, and doing 6 study visits.  Payment for completing this study is $500.  To see if you would be a good fit, please visit www.PEERSstudy.org or call 919-966-5243.

This study was approved on 5/03/2018 by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Biomedical IRB, Study# 13-3572.

subject: Graduate Student Health Insurance Program - Enrollment for 2018-19 and Other Issues
author: shia
content:
To:       Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

From:   Dwayne Pinkney, CFO and Senior Associate Vice Chancellor, Finance and Administration; Brian T. Smith, Assistant Vice Chancellor for Finance; Ken Pittman, Executive Director, Campus Health Services

Re:       Graduate Student Health Insurance Program – Enrollment for 2018-19 and Other Issues

In August 2009, the UNC Board of Governors approved the implementation of a “hard waiver” student health insurance plan on all sixteen 4-year campuses beginning in fall 2010. The term “hard waiver” means any graduate or undergraduate student meeting three specific criteria (enrolled in a minimum of 6 credit hours if an undergraduate or 1 credit hour if a graduate student, degree-seeking, and eligible to pay the student health fee) is required to show evidence of an existing “creditable coverage” health insurance policy or purchase a creditable insurance policy OR enroll in the UNC system-wide plan.

Graduate students enrolled in the Graduate Student Health Insurance Program (GSHIP), frequently referred to as the RA/TA Health Insurance Plan, must submit an online waiver using their GSHIP insurance at  www.bcbsnc.com/unc or they will be charged $1,311.50 each semester on their University account for the system wide Student Blue insurance plan available to all undergraduate and graduate students.

The UNC Chapel Hill GSHIP plan is a separate insurance plan from the system wide Student Blue insurance plan. Graduate students functioning as Research Assistants (RA), Teaching Assistants (TA), Fellows, or Trainees should continue to be enrolled in the GSHIP plan each semester through their academic program. RA/TA’s should not enroll themselves in the system wide Student Blue insurance plan available to all undergraduates and graduate students.

Due to ongoing state and federal regulatory changes in health care and the insurance marketplace, UNC General Administration has been reviewing all University sponsored health plans system-wide.  Effective with the 2014-2015 plan year, the RA/TA Plan was no longer offered as an employer provided plan and enrollees do not have access to COBRA upon discontinuation of the plan.

Other GSHIP plan benefits remain the same and require fewer out of pocket expenses than the system wide Student Blue insurance plan. The system wide Student Blue insurance plan cannot be substituted for the GSHIP plan.

The insurance program for graduate students is separate from insurance programs for Clinical Fellows, Postdoctoral Trainees, and Postdoctoral Research Associates. The purpose of this memorandum is to provide information regarding the 2018-19 enrollment process for the Graduate Student Health Insurance Program as well as other pertinent information. The 2018-19 policy year is from August 1, 2018 through July 31, 2019.

For the 2018-19 policy year the minimum prescribed compensation amount for services that a student must receive is $5,700.00. The premium cost per student for annual coverage during the current policy year under the program, provided through Blue Cross Blue Shield of NC, is $3994.92 ($332.91 per month). The Campus Health Fee is $200.08 per semester ($400.15 per academic year) for fiscal year 2018-19.

Please note the following:

For the 2018-19 policy year BCBS will not automatically waive graduate students that are enrolled in the GSHIP insurance. Students must complete an online waiver or be charged for the system wide Student Blue insurance plan.  The fall waiver deadline is September 10, 2018 and the spring waiver deadline is January 31, 2019.

To ensure students receive their GSHIP BCBS policy ID card prior to August 1st the department must enroll their RA/TA’s into GSHIP with ample time to receive their cards.  Enrollment must be completed even for those students currently on the GSHIP plan. If enrollments are not received by BCBSNC prior to August 15, 2018, students will receive a HIPAA certificate from BCBSNC stating coverage terminated July 31, 2018.  If they feel they have received the letter in error, they will be directed to their academic program/department for any questions concerning receipt of this letter.

Effective August 1, 2015 retroactive enrollments or terminations exceeding 60 days will no longer be allowed for administrative errors.  Exceptions for extenuating circumstances (delays due to death, hospitalization, etc.) will only be considered.

The following policy, procedures, forms and manual (see links below) provide detailed information about the Graduate Student Health Insurance Plan. Please review all documents.

Policy 1112 – Graduate Student Health Insurance Program (GSHIP) - Eligibility Criteria and Other Provisions of the Health Insurance Plan (http://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112 )
Procedure 1112.1 – Verifying Student Eligibility for GSHIP (http://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112_1 )
Form - 1112.1.1f – Graduate Student Health Insurance Program Verification of Student Eligibility (https://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112_1_1f )
Procedure 1112.2 – Enrolling in the Graduate Student Health Insurance Program (GSHIP) (http://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112_2 )
Procedure 1112.3 – Paying Graduate Students (http://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112_3)
Procedure 1112.4 – Paying GSHIP Insurance Premium (http://financepolicy.unc.edu/1112_4 )

The information in this memorandum is the result of extensive discussions among academic and administrative departments concerning appropriate procedures and practices for the Graduate Student Health Insurance Program. Your additional comments regarding the efficiency and effectiveness of the procedures and practices are most welcome as efforts to improve the program administration.

Please notify the following individuals regarding your questions or comments. Thank you for your continued efforts regarding the Graduate Student Health Insurance Program.

subject: Protocol for Responding to Campus Visits by Federal and State Agents
author: hunan
content:
Memo to Deans, Directors, and Department Heads:

This memorandum provides guidance on responding to requests from federal and state agents for information about a student, faculty, or staff member. These requests may be presented in person, over the phone, or in writing. 

University employees must refer any inquiry from a federal or state agency regarding a student, faculty, or staff member to the UNC Police Department so a UNC police officer can verify the credentials of the agent.  Additionally, University employees must contact the Office of University Counsel prior to releasing information regarding a student, faculty, or staff member.

Contacting UNC Police and the Office of University Counsel before disclosing information about students, faculty, and staff is necessary in order to comply with University policies and applicable laws. Specifically, the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) generally prohibits disclosing information about students without the student’s consent. Similarly, the North Carolina Human Resources Act generally prohibits disclosing confidential personnel information without the employee’s consent. 

We are including links to two resources with this memo:

A Q&A document
A PDF desk reference card to print and use
These resources are designed to assist faculty, staff, and students in knowing what steps to take should they receive such inquiries, including which campus offices to immediately contact. Please distribute this information to your faculty and staff, and especially to those employees who may serve as the first point of contact for your respective areas.

Should you have questions, please contact Elizabeth Barnum, director of international student and scholar services, at 919.962.5661.

Sincerely,
Ron Strauss
Executive Vice Provost and Chief International Officer

subject: Healthy Controls Needed FIT-NV Study
author: rrblanch
content:
The UNC Center for Functional GI and Motility Disorders is recruiting healthy men and women over the age of 18 for a research study. We are investigating the normal values for anal and rectal pressures in the general population. This information will be used to distinguish normal from abnormal results when the diagnostic equipment is used.

For this particular study, we are asking you to fill out a series of questionnaires and participate in two commonly used diagnostic procedures, called anorectal manometry and a balloon evacuation test. Both tests are currently used in clinics to help diagnose lower GI disorders. No treatment or diagnosis will be given during this research study.

You will receive $150 for completing the research study.

This study is sponsored by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Institute of Diabetes, Digestive, and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK). If you are interested in learning more about this research study, please call or email a member of the study staff to learn more.

Study Contact: Stefanie Twist 919-843-6961; sjeremia@med.unc.edu
Biomedical IRB 17-2777 approved on April 26, 2018.

subject: Healthy Microbiome Research Study
author: jlgage
content:
Healthy Microbiome Research Study


Are you a healthy woman interested in helping us to better understand bladder and vaginal health?  Then the Healthy Microbiome Study may be right for you!


UNC Researchers are looking for healthy adult women (18-70+) to participate in a study to help us better understand the genitourinary microbiome.  The genitourinary microbiome is a collection of microorganisms (bacteria) that live inside the bladders and vaginas of healthy women. 

We are doing this study in order to understand more about the bladders of healthy women by investigating the role of microbiologic factors as they relate to a woman’s own bladder health.  We hope that by identifying what a “healthy” microbiome looks like, we will then be able to identify women who may be at increased risk of developing bladder problems at some point in their life.  This information would revolutionize our approach to bothersome bladder conditions and change our view from one of treating a symptom to actually preventing the development of a disorder altogether.

Participation involves:

8 short visits over a 1-year time period (average one visit every 6 weeks)
Collection of voided urine specimens and self-collected vaginal swabs
Completion of a few short questionnaires
Participants can earn up to $100 in compensation for their time and participation

Eligibility
• Female gender
• At least 18 years old
• Willing to participate in a study over a 1-year time period

Principal Investigator
Dr. Alexis Dieter
Urogynecology and Reconstructive Pelvic Surgery at UNC Chapel Hill

For information contact:
Healthy Microbiome Study Research Team
3032 Old Clinic Bldg. CB# 7570
Chapel Hill, NC 27599
Phone: 919-843-8259
uncpelvichealth@med.unc.edu 

Biomedical IRB approval #17-3239 1/8/2018, Microbiologic Determinants of Self-Perceived Bladder Health.

subject: DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION? DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?
author: memclamb
content:
DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION?

DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?

The Department of Psychiatry at both Duke and UNC-CH are working together on a research study to help develop new interventions for people who are experiencing low levels of motivation and pleasure.

 

We are looking for people between the ages of 18-50 who are not currently taking any psychiatric medications and/or not currently in psychotherapy and are experiencing symptoms of low motivation and pleasure. Symptoms of low motivation and pleasure can include not wanting to be with other people, not wanting to participate in activities that you previously enjoyed, and feeling numb to the joys of life. Volunteers must be willing to provide informed consent to complete an initial clinical interview, questionnaires regarding mood, anxiety, quality of life, brain scans before and after treatment, and the possibility of two additional brain scans during treatment.

There is no cost to participate.
You will receive up to 15 psychotherapy sessions from a Duke clinician.
You will receive compensation for the portions of the study you complete.
To see if you qualify, complete this online survey: https://redcap.unc.edu/surveys/?s=NN99MR9EA8UNC-CH Biomedical IRB approved on March 9, 2018 IRB Number: 16-2268

subject: UNC Travel Reminders
author: hunan
content:
Dear Students, Faculty and Staff:

Each year, hundreds of people in the Carolina community travel internationally for important academic, research, and outreach opportunities.  We would like to remind you of university requirements and resources that can help inform your plans for safe and productive international travel.

UNC Global Travel Registry 
(http://globaltravel.unc.edu)

Anyone traveling internationally in affiliation with the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill must register the trip in the university's Global Travel Registry.  The Global Travel Registry is a secure database of itineraries and contact information for students, faculty, and staff traveling abroad in connection with UNC.  The information travelers provide is restricted to authorized departmental and university administrators and is used only to facilitate communication with those who may be in a global crisis situation.  Some students on approved programs offered through the Office of Study Abroad or through a professional school administrator may be pre-registered and, in such instances, would not need to register independently.  For more information, please see https://global.unc.edu/travel-info/global-travel-registry or contact Andrew Hunt in the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost at 919.962.3622 or andrew.hunt@unc.edu.

Insurance Coverage Abroad 
http://global.unc.edu/travel-info/travel-insurance-and-risk-management

Anyone traveling abroad in affiliation with the university must also enroll in the international health, evacuation, and repatriation insurance program established by the UNC System Office and administered by GeoBlue.  To enroll, please contact Janet Hoernke in Risk Management Services at 919.962.6681 or janet_hoernke@unc.edu.  Some students on approved programs offered through the Office of Study Abroad or through a professional school administrator may be pre-enrolled and, in such instances, would not need to enroll independently.  For other travel not affiliated with UNC, we encourage you to review your insurance coverage before traveling and, if necessary, consider purchasing a supplemental policy to cover you while abroad.

Travel Warnings and Alerts 
(http://global.unc.edu/travel-info/state-department-travel-warnings)

The university monitors State Department Travel Advisories, CDC Travel Health Notices, and daily world news briefings and security alerts.  In accordance with this and other available information, the university assigns an appropriate travel risk level for each world country.  Travel to countries with elevated risk levels caries certain implications for university-related travel.  Click the link above for a list of countries with elevated travel risks as well as information on additional requirements for traveling to these nations.

 For additional travel information, resources, and tips visit: http://global.unc.edu/travel-info.

subject: Research Opportunity for New and Expecting Mothers
author: angwyn
content:
Have you ever wondered why some babies are bold while others are cautious?

Have you ever thought the answer might be in the human gut?

GUT MICROBIOTA AND ANXIETY is a research study at UNC Chapel Hill exploring how organisms living in the human gut affect brain development and babies’ responses to new situations. We are currently recruiting pregnant women and new mothers.
Details are below. Please share this message with friends and family. 

Participants receive: 
- $200 per visit (potential total of $400) 
- Reimbursement for mileage and parking 

Who can participate in this study? To be in this study, your child must be exclusively breastfed (no formula, gripe water, or sugar water) until the first study visit. Babies cannot be in the study if they receive formula or antibiotics before the first study visit.

What does this study involve? When your child is 2 weeks old he/she will receive a MRI scan of the brain. We will also collect a small blood sample via heel prick and several samples of saliva (spit). When your child is 1 year old, we will observe how he/she responds to new people and toys. He/she will also receive a MRI scan at this visit. We will collect a small blood sample via heel prick and spit samples as before. We will also ask you to collect fecal (stool) samples from your child prior to both visits.

Why participate in this study? Research is designed to benefit society by gaining new knowledge. By participating you and your child may help us better understand and prevent psychiatric problems in future generations. The benefits to your child from being in this study may be the opportunity to have a thorough evaluation of his or her brain and early behavior.

Are there any risks? There is no evidence that MRI scans have any harmful effects. MRIs do not use x-rays or radiation. Children are scanned during natural sleep. Heel pricks will be done by trained personnel with supplies designed to minimize discomfort.
Remember:  this is a voluntary study, no medicine or sedation is involved, you will be compensated, and all information gathered is confidential.

How do I learn more about joining this study?  Call Jennifer Prater, study coordinator, at (919) 843-5902 or (866) 849-0541 (Toll Free), or send an email to jennifer_prater@med.unc.edu with your name, phone number and times that you can be reached. This is a confidential study: we will not share your email address with anyone outside of the study. 

This research study is funded by the National Institute of Health.

The Early Brain Development Study and this message have received approval on May 1st, 2017 from the UNC Biomedical IRB, Study # 14-0932

subject: Update on N.C. Free Speech Act, Policies and Campus Resources
author: janerc
content:
To Students, Faculty and Staff:

Carolina is committed to fostering an environment where intellectual engagement flourishes and campus community members are free to express their opinions and ideas. 

As a public institution, the University must uphold the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, as well as the General Assembly’s North Carolina Restore and Preserve Free Speech Act and a Board of Governors policy on free speech and free expression in the UNC System, both enacted in 2017.

The University is sending this message in accordance with the Board of Governors free speech and free expression policy.

In certain circumstances, the University may restrict when, where and how First Amendment rights are exercised, but in doing so, the campus may not prohibit expression because the content is unpopular, offensive, or even hateful. The University established the Policy on Use of University Facilities for Noncommercial and Commercial Purposes and Policy on Access and Use of Buildings consistent with these standards.

Issues regarding free speech on campus can be complex. To assist students, faculty and staff, the University has designated the following responsible officers to serve as resources about policies that affect the exercise of speech:

Jean Elia, Associate Provost
jelia@email.unc.edu; (919) 962-2624

Becci Menghini, Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Workforce Strategy, Equity and Engagement
becci_menghini@unc.edu; (919) 843-0594

Jonathan Sauls, Dean of Students
jsauls@email.unc.edu; (919) 966-4045

Kim Strom-Gottfried, Director, Office of Ethics Education and Policy Management
ksg@unc.edu; (919) 962-6495

Please feel free to reach out to these administrators with any questions or concerns.

subject: Infant/Toddler Development Screening
author: sallie7
content:
Parents and Infants Engaged (PIE) Study

IRB #17-0292; Non-Biomedical IRB Approval Date: March 25th, 2017

 

Do you want to learn more about your infant’s development?

How:

Participate in a research study to better understand early signs of developmental concerns in infants 11 through 16 months of age and test a free home-based intervention.

What you do:

Complete a brief screening tool about your infant:

Go online to complete the screening tool at https://is.gd/PIEstudy
OR ask for a paper copy by contacting the study by email at PIEstudy@unc.edu or by calling 919-842-9582 at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
What will happen next:

We are looking for both infants who show high risk on the screening tool to offer a free developmental assessment.
If the assessment results confirm that your child is a good candidate for the intervention, we will invite you to participate in that part of the study. The intervention will be provided in your home for 1 hour per week for 12 weeks. A coach will help you use strategies to help your child develop.
We will offer information for other intervention services if needed. You can decide at any point whether to continue with the study.
 

Principal Investigators: Drs. Linda Watson and Grace Baranek, Department of Allied Health Sciences, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

Contact us: PIEstudy@unc.edu or 919-842-9582

subject: Autism Parent Retreat
author: sallie7
content:
First Annual

NORTH CAROLINA

AUTISM PARENT RETREAT

Relaxing Mind, Body, and Soul

July 27th– 29th, 2018

St. Francis Springs Prayer Center, Stoneville, NC



What is the purpose? To give parents the opportunity to reflect on their journey as a parent of a child with autism, and spend time with other parents in a relaxing, casual, and accepting atmosphere. 

Who should attend? The retreat is meant for couples, and any kind of couple is welcome.  Married couples, partners, parent of a child on the spectrum and a supportive relative or friend. 

What happens there? Parents will have opportunities for relaxation, discussion, networking, making new friends, and learning from other parents.  This is not a conference, it is a retreat.  There are no “required” sessions.  There will be facilitated discussions and activities, but this is meant to be a place to share experiences, eat good food, and relax.

What is the cost? It costs $500.00 for a couple to attend this retreat. Couples will be expected to invest a non-fundable $50.00 payment upon registration. This includes 2 nights stay and 6 meals.



Register now to join us! Availability for the 2018 retreat is limited!



For registration information contact:

Seanyea Rains, Autism Society of NC, State Chapter Director

srains@autismsociety-nc.org

 

Sponsored by: The Autism Society of North Carolina, The UNC-CH TEACCH Autism Program and The UNC-CH Allied Health Sciences’ Program for Early Autism Research Leadership and Service (PEARLS)

subject: Erskine Bowles Staff Service Award Nominations Open
author: mbanks
content:
Overview
The goal of the UNC Staff Assembly is to improve communications, understanding and morale throughout the whole of our respective communities and to increase efficiency and productivity in campus operations. In as much, the Erskine B. Bowles Staff Service Award is given to a permanent, full-time staff member who has shown exemplary understanding, empathy and devotion to mankind and whose accomplishments are consistent with the goals exemplified by Erskine B. Bowles during his tenure as UNC President and in accordance with the University's public service mission.


Public Service in the University of North Carolina
Service to the state has always been a core part of the University’s mission. Our staff, like their faculty colleagues, are engaged in public service activities on our campuses and throughout the state which makes the University an integral part of the state’s economic and cultural life. Staff serve the people of North Carolina by directly engaging with the specific needs of businesses, nonprofit groups and governments bringing to life the strategies stated in the UNC Strategic Directions Plan: Our Time, Our Future. UNC must continue to take a prominent role in working within communities to assist in meeting the needs of today’s society.

Selection Criteria
• Permanent staff member from any of the 17 institutions and University affiliate groups
• Demonstrates exceptional customer service
• Provides extraordinary assistance by providing additional help outside of normal job responsibilities throughout the campus and surrounding communities
• Displays selfless acts of giving to the campus and community events
• The creativity and impact of a nominee’s achievements are of a magnitude that greatly exceeds the normal accomplishments of a staff employee


Nomination Process / Required Items
We are pleased to announce that nominations are being sought for the 2018 Erskine B. Bowles Staff Service Award. All institutions are urged to participate in this process. The deadline for nominations is 05/31/2018. Please submit your complete nomination packet to the UNC Staff Assembly Chair, Dawn Brown at brownmd@uncw.edu and UNC Staff Assembly HR Committee Chair, Carlitta Moore at cmmoore02@uncfsu.edu. Packets must include:


? A Letter of Nomination / Cover Letter from Campus Human Resources Department with a statement of the candidate’s contributions and demonstrated record of public service to the campus / local community
? A statement of the highlights of the candidate’s recent accomplishments related to the award and how it contributes to the overall welfare of the campus / local community
? Letters of Support (maximum 3) from peers, supervisor, students, campus administration, local community members, representatives from local businesses / organizations
? Nominee’s biographical information

subject: Infant/Toddler Sleep Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study
Hello,

The Frohlich Lab, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions.


In this research study, we are examining sleep characteristics in infants/toddlers that may have:


-Language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
-Delays in social communication or play 
-Autism or who are at-risk for autism (have a sibling with autism). 


Children develop and change rapidly during infancy and toddlerhood. We know that sleep is a critical aspect of health and brain development. However, little has been done to document patterns of sleep in young children or examine how brain activity during sleep may differ in children with delays and children with autism. 


~You may be eligible if:
· Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
. Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with delays in social communication or play
. Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with an autism spectrum disorder.
 · Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months who has an older sibling with an autism spectrum disorder.

~We schedule the two visits at your convenience and you will be with your child at all times. Each visit will take about 2- 2 ½ hours. The types of activities involved: 
. A visit to your home at your convenience: Infant developmental assessments 
. A visit to the nap room: Non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap. Your child will be playing with a variety of toys and taking a nap. This location offers free parking.

We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu. You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/.

We look forward to your participation!


The Frohlich Lab


This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/16/18 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: Autism and parenthood: 10% off "A" TRAIN at PlayMakers
author: rosalie
content:
ONE MOM’S JOURNEY ON THE AUTISM TRAIN
Hop on board the "A" TRAIN at PlayMakers, April 25-29. With your UNC Faculty/Staff Discount, you get 10% OFF tickets to the final production of the PlayMakers season.

When Amy learns that one of her young twins is autistic, she feels like her life is falling apart. She plunges into the world of autism, trying to piece together a new reality from the countless people she meets: parents, educators, teachers and especially other autistic individuals. Abounding with music, irreverent humor and verbatim interviews, the world of the play is part oral history project, part magical journey into the heartbeat of a different way of being. One woman plays multiple roles in this adventurous exploration of what it is to be human. In the process Amy is changed forever, learning to see the world, her son and the very nature of happiness with clearer eyes. 

"A" Train runs April 25 through 29. 

NEW THIS SEASON: Login with your ONYEN and receive the faculty/staff discount online! Or you can always visit or call the Box Office: 919.962.7529.


For more information, visit our website.

subject: Cultivating Clarity, Compassion, and Humor on the Parenting Journey with Dr. Caroline Hexdall
author: kmeason
content:
Mindful Parenting with Caroline Hexdall, Ph.D.
Sponsored by the UNC Program on Integrative Medicine

 

An approach to parenting that facilitates deeper connections with our children.

The Mindful Parenting Program is a research-based program developed by Susan Bögels and Kathleen Restifo and endorsed by Mark Williams, Christopher Germer and Jon and Myla Kabat-Zinn. Participants will explore themes such as parenting on "automatic pilot," beginner's mind parenting, responding vs. reacting to parenting stress, conflict and parenting, and love and limits. In addition, topics of self-compassion, vulnerability and wholeheartedness will be presented. Participants in the program will practice new ways of being present during joyful as well as stressful parenting moments. Mindful parenting is an approach to parenting that can allow for deeper connections with our children, creating a more peaceful, healthier and happier relationships.

Sessions are two hours, held once a week for four weeks 

Class Dates: Fridays, May 4 through May 25, 2018, from 9:30 - 11:30am

Location: UNC School of Social Work, Tate Turner Kuralt Building, Room 500, 325 Pittsboro Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27516

Free parking in Dogwood Deck, if needed (Parking Vouchers will be provided)

Begin to create a better sense of well-being in your family

Classes start soon and space is limited, if interested, please follow click here!

For more information, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfulness@med.unc.edu

Please visit our website for additional course information and like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: Infant Feeding Study
author: scarla
content:
We are currently seeking parents and their infants to participate in the LiTTLe Me: Learning Together to Love Mealtime Study, a research study on infant feeding and growth.

The purpose of this research study is to learn about how the interactions between parents and their infants during feeding affect infants’ growth. We also want to learn about the interest in and acceptability of educational training for parents related to feeding their infants. Finally, we want to make sure that the ways we collect data are acceptable for parents and infants.

You and your infant may be eligible if:

Your infant is between the age of 4-9 months old; 
Your infant has no developmental delays or disabilities that make it difficult for them to eat, drink, or communicate; 
You read, understand, and speak English or Spanish. 
The study involves three data collection sessions that take place in your home. Each data collection will last approximately 2.5 hours. Participants will receive a total of $90 for completing the study.

Please call 919-843-8554 or email scarla@email.unc.edu to learn more about the study. All information provided is confidential.

This research study has been approved by the Non-Biomedical UNC-CH IRB on 4/25/2016. IRB #15-2437.

subject: Water Certifications
author: crayers
content:
Did you know the Exercise and Sport Science deparment offers certification courses? 

Ever thought about learning to SCUBA dive?  You can train to be a certified SCUBA diver: 

PHYA 227. SCUBA. 1 Credit.

Required preparation, strong swimming skills. This course prepares students for participation in recreational diving: both skin diving and scuba. Lectures cover physiology of diving, first aid, and decompression. It can lead to certification if students attend open water training dives conducted at the semester's end. An additional fee is required.
Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 4 total credits. 4 total completions.
Grading status: Letter grade; credit hours may not be used toward degree.

 

Or have you ever thought teaching swimming, a potientially life-saving skill, to all age groups would be rewarding?  You can train to be an American Red Cross certified swim instructor:

PHYA 242. Water Safety Instructor. 1 Credit.

This course will train students to teach American Red Cross progressive swimming and water safety courses. Course content includes analysis of stroke mechanics, review of water safety skills, and investigation of teaching methodology. Students need to be proficient in front crawl, back crawl, elementary backstroke, breaststroke, and sidestroke.
Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 4 total credits. 4 total completions.
Grading status: Letter grade; credit hours may not be used toward degree.

 

Register now while there are spots in the classes still open!

subject: Early Voting for Orange County
author: sthurman
content:
To Carolina's Faculty, Staff and Students:


Election Day for the May primary for Orange County and Federal offices is Tuesday, May 8. Polls will be open from 6:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. on Election Day.  You can confirm your registration and find your election day polling place here.  The deadline to register to vote on Election Day has passed.

North Carolina allows same day voter registration during the early voting period from April 19 to May 5. If you live on campus or off-campus in Orange County, you may register, and vote, at any Orange County early voting site.

To register to vote during the early voting period, be sure to bring proof of residency that shows your name and current address. If you live on campus, Orange County election officials have a dorm roster and you may show your One Card as proof of residency.

If you are registered to vote in Orange County, or are eligible to use same-day registration at an Orange County early voting site, the closest early voting location to campus is the Chapel of the Cross, 304 E. Franklin St. (next to Morehead Planetarium). It will be open for early voting:

Saturday, April 21, 9 a.m. – 3 p.m.
Monday-Friday, April 23 – 27, noon – 6 p.m.
Monday-Friday, April 30 – May 4, noon – 6 p.m.
Saturday, May 5, 9 a.m. – 1 p.m.

Chapel of the Cross will not host early voting on Saturday, April 28.

Please check the Orange County Board of Elections website, or your home county’s Board of Elections website, for additional information about early voting locations and hours. During early voting, you may vote at any early voting location in your county of residence. You may also request a mail-in absentee ballot here.  Mail-in ballots requests must be RECEIVED by the Board of Elections by May 1.

As a reminder to faculty and staff, UNC employees are prohibited by law, (N.C. General Statute 126-13) and UNC Board of Governors' policy, from using the authority of their positions, or from using state funds, supplies or vehicles, to secure support for, or to oppose any candidate, party or issue in an election.

The University takes seriously the right of each person on campus to express personal opinions on matters of public concern. We also take seriously our obligation to comply with federal and state laws and UNC policies and to serve as responsible stewards of the public resources entrusted to us.

If you have questions about permissible political activity for employees, you can find additional guidance here.

This message is sponsored by: UNC Student Affairs

subject: Research Opportunity for New and Expecting Mothers
author: angwyn
content:
Have you ever wondered why some babies are bold while others are cautious?

Have you ever thought the answer might be in the human gut?

GUT MICROBIOTA AND ANXIETY is a research study at UNC Chapel Hill exploring how organisms living in the human gut affect brain development and babies’ responses to new situations. We are currently recruiting pregnant women and new mothers.


Details are below. Please share this message with friends and family. 

Participants receive: 
- $200 per visit (potential total of $400) 
- Reimbursement for mileage and parking 

Who can participate in this study? To be in this study, your child must be exclusively breastfed until the first study visit. Babies cannot be in the study if they receive formula, sugar water, gripe water, or antibiotics before the first study visit.

What does this study involve? When your child is 2 weeks old he/she will receive a MRI scan of the brain. We will also collect a small blood sample via heel prick and several samples of saliva (spit). When your child is 1 year old, we will observe how he/she responds to new people and toys. He/she will also receive a MRI scan at this visit. We will collect a small blood sample via heel prick and spit samples as before. We will also ask you to collect fecal (stool) samples from your child prior to both visits.

Why participate in this study? Research is designed to benefit society by gaining new knowledge. By participating you and your child may help us better understand and prevent psychiatric problems in future generations. The benefits to your child from being in this study may be the opportunity to have a thorough evaluation of his or her brain and early behavior.

Are there any risks? There is no evidence that MRI scans have any harmful effects. MRIs do not use x-rays or radiation. Children are scanned during natural sleep. Heel pricks will be done by trained personnel with supplies designed to minimize discomfort.
Remember:  this is a voluntary study, no medicine or sedation is involved, you will be compensated, and all information gathered is confidential.

How do I learn more about joining this study?  Call Jennifer Prater, study coordinator, at (919) 843-5902 or send an email to jennifer_prater@med.unc.edu with your name, phone number and times that you can be reached. This is a confidential study: we will not share your email address with anyone outside of the study. 

This research study is funded by the National Institute of Health.

The Early Brain Development Study and this message have received approval from the UNC Biomedical IRB, Study #14-0932

subject: Meet the Candidates of Director, University Ombuds
author: mtozzer

subject: Overcome your spider phobia
author: jonabram
content:
Are you afraid of spiders?

Do you find spiders disgusting or aversive?

Do you avoid spiders (or certain places/situations where you may encounter spiders)?

 

If you have any of the above spider concerns and you are age 18 and older, you may be eligible to participate in a research study on overcoming spider phobia being conducted at the University of North Carolina at no charge.

If you are interested, the first step is a 15 minute phone screen for us to tell you more about the study and confirm that you are eligible to participate. Please email spiderstudy@unc.edu with the following information:

(1) First name,

(2) Phone number, and

(3) Times you would be available to have a brief (15 minute) phone call.

  

Thanks,

Jennifer Buchholz

UNC Chapel Hill Clinical Psychology PhD Student

spiderstudy@unc.edu

 

 

Study Title: One-session treatment for spider fears

UNC-CH Nonbiomedical IRB # 15-1609

Approval date: 8/29/17

Expires 8/28/18

subject: Joyce Tan Named Associate Vice Chancellor for Research
author: briordan
content:
April 17, 2018

To:      Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs
From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research
Re:     Joyce Tan Named Associate Vice Chancellor for Research 

Dear Colleagues,

I am pleased to announce that Joyce Tan, PhD, has been named associate vice chancellor for research (AVCR) effective April 1, 2018.  As AVCR, Tan is a member of my executive leadership team and is responsible for advancing UNC’s research mission and overseeing the Office of Research Development. Tan has served as chief of research strategy for the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research (OVCR) since July of 2016.   

As associate vice chancellor for research, she promotes interdisciplinary integration, cultivating growth of the University’s global research reputation. Her responsibilities include working closely with leadership in University schools and the College, as well as pan-campus centers and institutes to design, facilitate collaboration and execute strategic, multidisciplinary initiatives such as the OVCR’s Creativity Hubs program. She also facilitates innovation and entrepreneurship by connecting the OVCR with leadership across UNC, and by promoting research partnerships with external public and private organizations.

Prior to working with the OVCR, Tan served as director of industry alliances within the School of Medicine and program manager for the Carolina Center for Genome Sciences and the Department of Genetics.  In these roles she conducted capacity building activities to attract extramural funding as well as, built and developed partnerships and alliances with pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.  Her scientific background is in immunology, and she has made important scientific contributions to vaccine development, the understanding of how T cells populate the immune system, and how T cells maintain memory to respond to subsequent infections.

Please join me in welcoming and supporting Joyce in her new role.

subject: Powerful Skills to Help Your Teen to Handle Stress One Moment at a Time
author: kmeason
content:
Making Friends with Yourself: A Mindful Self-Compassion Program for High School Teens (14-18 year old) 
Sponsored by the Program on Integrative Medicine
Information Session: Thursday, April 19, 2018 from 6-7 PM

The purpose of the session is to answer any questions folks have about the class, and to dispel any apprehension teens have about taking the class. It is NOT required, and open to anyone who is interested in taking it, and their parents. (No obligation to take the class if they come to the informational session).

UNC now offers a mindful self-compassion class for adolescents, ages 14-18. Mindful Self-Compassion brings together the benefits of mindfulness and self-compassion:  Mindfulness teaches us to be present with difficult emotions, and self-compassion helps us to respond to these emotions with greater kindness and self-care.

Through developmentally appropriate activities and meditations, teens learn specific tools, which help them, navigate the emotional difficulties of this life stage with greater ease.  A preliminary research study on this program has demonstrated significant decreases in depression, anxiety, perceived stress and negative mood from before to after taking this course.

Class Dates: Thursdays, April 26 through June 14, 2018

Instructors: Kate Murphy and Laura Prochnow Phillips

Time: 5:00-6:45PM

Location:UNC Center for Rehabilitation Care, 1807 Fordham Blvd., Chapel Hill NC 27514

To Register, click here!

For more information, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfulness@med.unc.edu

Please visit our website for additional course information and like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: CFE Summer Writing Group Program - Sign up here!
author: chelsja
content:
Working on a writing project?  Need motivation?

The 2018 CFE Summer Writing Group Program is now accepting registrations! 

 

The Center for Faculty Excellence sponsors the CFE Summer Writing Group (SWG) Program.

 

Since Summer 2013, the SWG Program brings faculty members from all disciplines and career stages to be in small groups to spur writing productivity and foster cross-disciplinary connections. The Program begins with an Orientation meeting in May that allows interested faculty members to meet with the groups to which they have been assigned on the basis of their expressed preferences. Groups meet regularly throughout the summer at times that suit them and have the freedom to structure their activities as they wish.

 

I see the Summer Writing Group program as one of the most valuable, pan-university programs that we offer. We are delighted to be working with additional research faculty for this year’s program and invite you to participate.

 

The Summer Writing Group Program Orientation Meeting will be held on Friday, May 4, 2018, 12:00PM-2:00PM (lunch included), Room 504 of Wilson Library. You can register here* by filling out a brief survey to collect writing group preferences. Deadline to register is Friday, April 27th, 2018. 

 

For any inquiries about this program or other CFE research programming, please direct questions to Erin Malloy at erin_malloy@med.unc.edu.

 




*If the link does not work above, please copy and paste the following sign-up link into your web browser: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3O8W594RSQ24bsN

subject: Paving the Way for Strong Proposals: Partnering with Stakeholders during the Proposal Development Continuum
author: maclay
content:
Stakeholder engagement is important to consider at all stages of any research process, including periods before grant submission.

Working with stakeholders during the proposal development process allows for the inclusion of stakeholder perspectives in the proposal and builds the foundation for strong partnerships that continue during research implementation and beyond.

If you are interested in hearing from experts about their experiences and best practices they use for involving stakeholders in all stages of the proposal development continuum, from idea generation to grant submission, contact NC TraCS. We can also share available mechanisms for compensating stakeholders in both the proposal development and research implementation phase.

To learn more, visit us here:https://tracs.unc.edu/index.php/calendar/2629

Thank you, 

NC TraCS

subject: Same-Sex Couples Counseling
author: pentel
content:
Are you interested in learning skills to improve/strengthen your relationship?

Do you disagree on topics related to being in a same-sex relationship (e.g., who to come out to or how to find a supportive social network?)

I specialize in working with couples and am conducting a small treatment research study of a no-cost couple therapy program. To be eligible for this pilot study, you and your partner must meet the following criteria:

-Living together more than 6 months
-Age 21 or older
-Identify as cisgender (biological/birth sex aligns with gender identity)
-Identify as female
-Have a certain level of distress in your relationship, including stress related to living in a heteronormative society (this will be assessed on the phone screen)

While we would hope for this program to be available to all couples, for the purpose of this initial pilot study we can only recruit a small sample of 12 couples. We hope to expand this program in the future. If you are not eligible for ACCESS, we can provide referrals to other appropriate couples counseling resources.

Questions? Interested in setting up an initial phone screening call to determine eligibility? Contact Kim (she/her) at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu or check out our website at: www.ACCESSprogram.web.unc.edu. All inquiries are confidential.

Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couple Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Nonbiomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: Are you 18-50 years old, healthy and interested in a clinical research study?
author: bcaudle
content:
We are interested in evaluating a new HIV antibody called VRC07-523LS that may be used in the future to prevent HIV infections. This study is recruiting healthy, HIV negative volunteers to learn more about the safety of the antibody and how it moves through body.

 

This study will last approximately 3 years with 23 study visits. Participants will receive the antibody 4 or 5 times as either an IV infusion or an injection under their skin. The research physician and nurse carefully monitor participants for side effects. This antibody is not a vaccine and the antibody will completely leave the body over several months.

 

You may be eligible if:

 
You are between the ages of 18-50 years old
You are HIV negative
You are in good health
You are willing to receive IV infusions and injections under the skin
You are not pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning on becoming pregnant for 3 years
You are able to attend study visits Monday- Friday between 7:30am-2pm.

 

Participants will be eligible to earn $25-100 per visit and up to $1,425 for completing all study visits.

 

If interested, please send an email to prevention_study@med.unc.edu with the following information:

 

Subject line: HPTN 087

 

Name

E-mail address

Phone number

Best time to be contacted

 

 

HVTN 127/HPTN 087: A multicenter, randomized phase 1 clinical trial to evaluate the safety and serum concentrations of a human monoclonal antibody, VRC-HIVMAB075-00-AB (VRC07-523LS), administered in multiple doses, routes, and dosing schedules to healthy, HIV-uninfected adults. IRB # 17-3285 Approved on 2018-02-21 by Fred Hutchinson IRB and 2018-02-27 by UNC Biomedical IRB

subject: NSF CAREER workshop
author: lindleyd
content:
NSF CAREER Workshop April 23, 3:00 – 4:30 pm 
Over the past few years, the Office of Research Development has organized programming around the NSF CAREER award with great feedback and success. This year we recruited past UNC CAREER winners to share their experiences with those who are interested in applying. We are planning a CAREER workshop to be held April 23, 3:00pm-4:30pm. 

The proposed agenda includes an overview of the CAREER program including tips and resources by Peter Mucha, a past NSF CAREER winner and Bowman and Gordon Gray Professor in the Department of Mathematics. Dr. Mucha led NSF CAREER mentoring efforts on campus the year UNC received 8 CAREER awards! Following Dr. Mucha, each CAREER winner attending will briefly share from their experience with the CAREER program. For the last portion of the workshop, we will offer time to break into small group sessions, where mentors will work in more detail with the applicants to answer their questions about the process or their research ideas. 

If you are interested, please email me, Denise Lindley at lindleyd@email.unc.edu to get more information. 

Thank you,
Denise Lindley
Office of Research Development

The Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research sponsors a small internal grant program, URC, for junior faculty at UNC-Chapel Hill. subject: Recruitment for  Muscle Quality and Aging Study
author: haydeng
content:
Hello,

    My name is Hayden Giuliani and I am a research coordinator in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science at UNC.  I am conducting a study that is examining how the quality of your muscles influences how your muscles change size when they contract and how this may influence how strong you are and how fast you walk.  For this study, we are looking for adult males between the ages of 65-74 years to complete two visits at the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science that will last approximately two hours (visit 1) and 45 minutes (visit 2). To qualify, you must have a BMI of 30 or above (formula below) and do not exercise for more than 3 hours per week. 

    You will perform a submaximal and maximal leg extension exercises of your thigh muscles with sensors taped to your muscles, and size and quality of your thigh muscles will be measured using ultrasonography while you are at rest, and during the strength assessments. For completing both visits associated with this study, you will receive $60 and free health information from the testing.  Please let me know if you have any questions and if you are interested in participating in our study. You can email me at haydeng@live.unc.edu or call me at 919-843-2014.

 

BMI = Weight (lb) ÷ Height (in) ÷ Height (in) × 703

 

Thank you for your time and I look forward to hearing from you!

 

Hayden Giuliani, MA, ATC, CSCS

Research Coordinator

Department of Exercise and Sport Science

UNC Chapel Hill



IRB #: 16-1523

Biomedical

Date Approved: 9/29/16

author: pruittj
content:
TO:                  All Deans, Directors, and Department Heads

FROM:            Sibby Anderson-Thompkins, Special Assistant to Vice Chancellor for

                        Research & Director, Office of Postdoctoral Affairs

DATE:            April 12, 2018

RE:                 2018 POSTDOCTORAL AWARDS FOR RESEARCH EXCELLENCE

The Office of Postdoctoral Affairs is pleased to accept applications this spring for Postdoctoral Awards for Research Excellence. The awards, open to postdocs in all disciplines, are designed to recognize research potential and to assist scholars with professional development needs, such as conference travel, written materials, skills workshops, or other activities that directly enhance the individual’s professional development. The awards can fund up to $1000 in professional endeavors and must be expended between July 1, 2018 and June 30, 2019.

Please encourage your postdocs conducting promising research to submit applications.

 I.  The following terms apply to the awards:
Applicants must be full-time and fall into one of two Human Resources designations: Postdoctoral Fellow/Trainee or Postdoctoral Research Associate.
Funds from the awards may be used for books, travel to a conference, skills workshops, or other resources or activities that directly enhance the postdoc’s professional development. Funds cannot be used to purchase computers or electronic equipment. Funds may only be used if the recipient is employed as a postdoc as UNC.  
The application deadline is 5:00PM on Friday, May 25, 2018.  

For more information regarding the application process, click here: http://research.unc.edu/offices/postdoctoral-affairs/postdocs/postdoc-research-excellence-awards/

subject: Tai Chi & Breast Cancer Study
author: atpiepme
content:
Dear Sir/Madam:

The purpose of this email is to inform you about a research study being conducted by the Program on Integrative Medicine at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill titled “Feasibility of an 8-week Tai Chi Chuan Intervention for Breast Cancer Survivors”.

At the end of this email, there is a link to a short questionnaire to see if you are eligible to participate.

General Study Information

This research study is designed to help us understand the feasibility of conducting a Tai Chi Class for people who are experiencing cognitive impairment following treatment for Breast Cancer.

Often termed “chemo brain” or “chemo fog”, cancer-related cognitive impairment could be experienced as having difficulties with memory, focus/attention, or multi-tasking.

Those eligible to participate in the research study will take part in an 8-week group Tai Chi Class located in a beautiful off-campus yoga studio in Carrboro. The group will meet twice per week and each class will last one hour and 15 minutes. Free parking is provided and the studio is on the bus route.

As part of the research study, participants will also come to the UNC campus on four occasions to complete assessments (free parking provided). The first two visits will be prior to beginning the Tai Chi class, and the final two visits will be after the 8-week Tai Chi period. The assessments will involve filling out questionnaires, telling us about your medical health, performing a variety of cognitive tasks, as well as collecting measurements of brain activity using EEG.

Take the questionnaire! We'll let you know if you're eligible and provide further information on how to get started.

For more information, please visit taichistudy.web.unc.edu or contact Dr. Aaron Piepmeier at atpiepme@med.unc.edu. Biomedical IRB Study#: 17-0141; pproval date 3/12/2018.





Thank you,

Aaron Piepmeier

Tai Chi & Breast Cancer Study

Program on Integrative Medicine

Department of Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation

University Of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Search free text (unstructured) clinical notes from the electronic health record with EMERSE
author: maclay
content:
What is EMERSE?

EMERSE can be thought of like “Google” for clinical notes. EMERSE can support a variety of tasks, including clinical and translational research, internal quality improvement and quality assurance initiatives, as well as hospital operational support tasks. EMERSE is designed to be user-friendly and intuitive and does not require IT or informatics experience.

What data are included in EMERSE?

EMERSE contains fully identified clinical notes from UNC Health Care. All data in EMERSE are considered protected health information (PHI) under HIPAA and should be treated as such. Here at UNC, EMERSE has tens of millions of documents, sourced from the Epic electronic health record.

Who can use EMERSE?

EMERSE users must:

Be paid employees of UNC-Chapel Hill
or UNC Health Care. Students may only receive access to EMERSE if they are paid employees/interns etc. (i.e., in UNC’s

HR system)

Meet the necessary regulatory requirements

Complete the required training

Learn more and sign up for training  at tracs.unc.edu/emerse

Brought to you by the NC TraCS BIOMEDICAL INFORMATICS Team

subject: A Follow Up to the Memo 2018 Federal Withholding Tax Changes and How They May Affect You
author: jlkelly
content:
Dear University Employee,

Beginning with the February 16, 2018, biweekly paycheck, all biweekly and monthly paychecks subject to federal tax withholdings reflect the 2018 federal tax withholding rates issued by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). As we shared with you in a February communication, the federal tax rate changes are a part of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed in December 2017.

The law increased the standard deduction, removed personal exemptions, increased the child tax credit, limited or discontinued certain deductions and changed the tax rates and brackets.  Due to these changes along with others, the IRS is recommending that all employees perform a paycheck checkup by using the Withholding Calculator on www.irs.gov/withholding. This website contains more information concerning the Withholding Calculator and Federal Tax Withholding Tables.

The Withholding Calculator can help employees estimate their 2018 annual income tax liability, and based on its recommendations, can help prevent too little or too much income tax from being withheld.  The withholding calculator compares the annual income tax estimate to the employee’s current income tax withholding and can help them decide if they need to change their withholding.  Employees using the calculator will find it helpful to have their completed 2017 tax return accessible and most recent paystub.  Employees are also encouraged to contact their tax professional should they have questions on how to accurately complete the information contained on the withholding calculator.

Employees can use the results from the Withholding Calculator to determine if they should complete a new Form W-4, Employee’s Withholding Allowance Certificate. Form W-4 can be submitted electronically via the ConnectCarolina Self-Service menu.

If you have problems accessing the ConnectCarolina Self-Service items, please contact the Help Desk. If after working with the Help Desk you are unable to update your W-4 please contact Payroll Services at payroll@unc.edu for assistance.

Walter Miller
Director of Payroll Services

subject: A new look for ConnectCarolina login landing page
author: hashk
content:
Starting on April 11, you will see a new layout when you type connectcarolina.unc.edu into your browser. You’ll see the same links you’re used to seeing plus a few extra. The new page will be easier to use for those new to ConnectCarolina and for students’ family members who only occasionally log in to ConnectCarolina. 

What is the connectcarolina.unc.edu website?

This is the page that we typically refer to as the “landing page” for ConnectCarolina and it’s distinguished by the two green buttons to access ConnectCarolina as well as an announcements section and other useful links. It’s the first page that you see before logging into ConnectCarolina.   



The Changes

We‘ve simplified the page layout and made it is easier to navigate. The links work the same as they do now. Only the look is different.
Looking for the InfoPorte link? It’s in ConnectCarolina under Enterprise Reporting on the left.
For Students

The first column on the updated webpage is for students and their proxy users. Like today, students will click the big green button to get to the ConnectCarolina Student Center, and once in ConnectCarolina, everything will work the same as it does now. 

Parents or others can pay bills or see student info by clicking the blue buttons in the lower left.  (As always, students first need to give them access.)

Click the first link under the green button, Useful Links for Students to go to a friendlier version of the page students currently use.

For Faculty, Staff, and Affiliates

Important links for Faculty, Staff and Affiliates are in the middle column.  We’ve added a few extra links to online and classroom training, online documentation and the ConnectCarolina User Info website.

The third column includes Useful Links, Security Information and the Announcements section. 

Questions?

Send an email to cc_communications@unc.edu if you have questions or concerns. There is no associated outage and it will not impact registration or other work in ConnectCarolina.
